content: On Keeping a Travel Notebook My summer in Europe was full of remarkable moments — but I forgot to write any of them down Amanda Oliver Blocked Unblock Follow Following Mar 19 Photos: Amanda Oliver On a Tuesday in March of 2013, hidden in the back room of the Washington, D.C. elementary school library where I worked, I felt myself giving up. On my choice of career and on myself. I was unhappy in the way people in their mid-twenties often are. I felt certain that my two degrees meant I was an adult, but also that I was waiting for an actual adult to tell me what to do. It was my second year working in a school, and I was still anxious at the beginning and end of every day. That March, my first-grade students were working on a unit about maps and my library was home to 20 globes for them to use as reference. They were situated like orbs on top of the bookshelves I had been painstakingly stocking and reorganizing for a year and a half. The world seemed smaller and manageable when I looked at the globes. For first graders, though, globes are confusing. Why can’t I go from D.C. to California if it is only the length of my palm? one asked, pressing his small hand across the continent, middle fingers dipping into the Pacific, almost touching Hawaii. We talked, again, about map scale and I could feel their disappointment with the answer. When my students left for the day I put a globe on my lap, closed my eyes, and spun it. When I opened them my finger was somewhere in the middle of Africa, holding the world still. I felt an impulsive rush. A summer vacation suddenly felt like exactly what I needed and I booked a one-way ticket to London. The spine I was hoping to stuff with experiences and descriptions instead got filled with my worries. From March to the end of June, I secluded myself in the back workroom whenever time allowed and I booked different legs of the trip. I’d only ever traveled to Canada, never outside of North America. I signed up for a help exchange website—a way to secure temporary employment in exchange for shelter and meals—and started to hunt for opportunities: a medicinal garden in Spain, an organic farm in Hungary, helping an older woman with house cleaning in a small town in the Netherlands. I purchased travel insurance, booked hostels and Airbnbs, and chose cities and countries, tracing their locations on one of the library globes. By April, I was helping to administer standardized tests and had a 10-country, two-month itinerary scrawled on Post-it notes stuck to the table where I fixed the spines and pages of broken books. A few days after the school year ended, I carefully filled a large red backpack a friend lent me. The date of my departure, June 27th, 2013 is captured on the first page of a new notebook: I’m here. It’s starting. My arm is rubbed raw from my backpack straps — I’m a pack mule now! When I was little I would write in my old diaries with the idea of my daughter someday reading them. I think I thought I would have her by now — instead I have this trip (and many other insteads, too!). Maybe someday she will read this, if there is a she to read. I had a panic attack there, in the Washington Dulles airport. The only hint in my notebook is that the second paragraph has a few smeared words from water spots. (It is more enjoyable, even now, to believe that these marks are from the weeks ahead, from the Amsterdam canal, or drops out of the Danube, but I know they are from my doubtful tears.) During my three years as a librarian, I fit writing into the hours after work. When the sun had set, but my fingers still had something to say. Writing took place in the tiny spaces of time I made for myself when my body felt exhausted, but the center of my chest was wide awake. I knew when I booked my trip that I would use this time, this endless free time, to write. I knew whatever notebook I brought with me would be one I’d cherish for the rest of my life. I knew these things until I actually left and tried to write in one. Visitors enjoying the Blue Lagoon in Grindavík, Iceland The first country I traveled to was Iceland. I only had one full day in the country and planned to visit the Blue Lagoon. The second page of my notebook reads: “The blue lagoon was beautiful, of course.” This was, apparently, the best I could do. Now, when I look back at pictures, I wish I had described the milky blue water and how I pretended I was sinking into a bowl of Easter egg dye. That its color matched the patent-leather Mary Jane shoes I wore when I was three or four. I wonder why I did not describe its warmth and the way I positioned myself by one vat of the lagoon’s minerals to listen as couples and children approached, giggling as they rubbed the contents onto one another’s faces and shoulders. I was alone, but I was happy. When I think of anyone traveling for more than a few weeks, I assume they bring a notebook. The pages from my brief visit to Iceland are filled with worries and wanting to move on to the next destination. I briefly mention hearing a man playing trombone in a room I could not find at the airport and I wish I had lingered there instead of worrying about how I appeared ( Did a girl scribbling in her notebook look…crazy? Lonely? ). The airport was under construction and many areas were closed off. Sitting in a small circle of café tables surrounded by caution tape, I swore I heard a muffled trombone behind a closed door, a sound I was used to hearing from my middle and high school band days. The auditory version of riding a bike — no matter how it’s been, you always remember. I boarded the plane to London without ever seeing anyone exit a room with a trombone. London is no better described in my notebook. I briefly mention meeting a woman named Kari and immediately move to complaining about how I always end up next to children on airplanes. I wrote “Hopefully Nice will be nice” before I’d even landed in London. Where is the space for the two-hour long conversation I had with Kari? Any admission that I overpacked and threw two pairs of shoes, a sweatshirt, a dress, and a backpack into an airport trash can upon arrival? Where is the description of the way London smelled — I can’t remember now — when I got off of the plane or how Kari and I decided, together, to sneak into Westminster Abbey rather than paying? The London Eye on a gray day Nice was nice. Nowhere in my notebook will it tell you that I saw the Tour de France, though. That I stood inches from the cyclists as they whizzed by the downtown area or that I hitchhiked for the first time in my life with a BBC reporter. The reporter and I ended up in a car with a French man who talked about his dislike of Americans the entire drive. There is nothing about how my feet got cut open from running barefoot to catch the last of a fireworks display with an Irish man I had met earlier in the day. That we could have slept on the beach together, but I panicked in the middle of making out with him and gave a taxi driver every bill and coin of money I had in my purse to take me back to my hostel at 2 a.m. There is no report on the pushy Portuguese man who, at sunset on the beach, offered me a tiny balloon that, years later, I would realize was heroin. When he asked me to walk just over there so we could try it together, I put it in my purse and excused myself back to the small group of women I had just met. The next morning, when I checked out of the hostel, I left the balloon in the locker I’d used to store my belongings. One fisherman with three poles on a beach in Nice When I think of anyone traveling for more than a few weeks, I assume they bring a notebook. Even people who never write must have a desire to take some sort of notes about their experiences, right? The pressure I put on my own notebook (the notebook of a writer, I kept reminding myself) was immense. In each entry, I try a new way of recording all that was happening, of perfecting my understanding of, and participation in, all these new places. I fly from France to Spain next. Spend a few days in Barcelona before taking a bus deep into Catalonia. During my seven-day work exchange at a medicinal garden in Balaguer, Spain, I write: JORDI’S 7/8/13 WORK: Melsa tea, sorting grains, lavender tea, malva tea. Early breakfast (7:30) said goodbye to Eli, then work. Sorting grains, making tea. Cold, hard facts. Nothing to elaborate on the five people I was working with. Nothing to tell about Jordi, the mighty man behind a slow-food movement who studies plants and is letting us all stay in his apartment with him. Each day we sort grains and make tea at a folding table, listening to the Catalan band Manel on Adrià from Barcelona’s phone, surrounded by Jordi’s massive marijuana plants on his back patio. At dinner we each eat one arsenic-soaked almond as a type of vitamin (Jordi says), and for dessert and digestion we chew on the carob we soak in our water glasses during the meal. Some of our food is cooked by solar power and all of it is vegan. I am surprised there is no mention even of the awful way my body adjusts to a garden-fresh vegan diet on the third day. Just a note that I feel like I am gaining weight and it bothers me. Jordi on his back patio completing one final sorting of the grains he uses to make bread in Balaguer By early July, two weeks into my travels, my notebook almost entirely becomes to-do lists, website links, jotted notes, walking and public transportation directions, reference numbers for flights. The handwriting does not look like my own. It ignores the straight lines the notebook has provided. It is large and chaotic. There is nothing written about the nine days I spent wandering bridges and streets in Budapest. That I stayed near the House of Terror, a museum with exhibits related to the fascist and communist regimes in 20th-century Hungary, and watched an elderly woman collapse in the basement there, surrounded by torture cells. Some of them had small windows where you could see the shadows of passing feet on the streets. Visitors were able to enter and stand in each one. I went to an organ concert at St. Stephen’s Basilica alone — the music from the organ built in 1905 shook the ground beneath my feet. I cried then, situated in the front row. The organ player smiled and winked at me from his seat onstage. The Chain Bridge lion at night with a lit-up Budapest surrounding him Missing, too, is the story of the very naked, very angry Hungarian man who yelled at me for sunbathing and taking photographs on a rooftop at Széchenyi thermal bath. I had no idea I had ventured onto the naturalist rooftop and that my bathing suit and photography were deeply offensive. His broken English and my complete lack of Hungarian meant the conversation carried on for quite a while before I skittered away from him and noticed a small sign near the entrance that read “Naturalist Rooftop Terrace” in English. At Király Baths I yelped when the masseuse whipped my bathing suit bottom off during the 15-minute massage included with the entry fee and began my kneading my butt. My notebook leaves out these embarrassments. Newspapers in a Viennese cafe The arrangements for my spontaneous visit to Vienna are not recorded either. I stayed 10 days just outside of Vienna in the small town of Klosterneuburg with a woman named Sigrid who had recently lost her father. In exchange for helping her clear all of the dead plants off of her patio and refinishing her outdoor furniture, she provided me with a private bedroom and all of my meals. Sigrid’s parents had given her a backpack when she was 14 and sent her on a solo trip to London that awakened her love of travel and hosting others. She introduced me to café culture and the Viennese phrase, “I don’t let myself be pushed.” In Germany, she tells me, it is a literal sentence. In Vienna, it speaks to strength and independence. Over drinks at the Museumsquartier, a place I visit four additional times for the many galleries filled with artwork by artists like Klimt and Schiele, she writes the words in my notebook for me. Hetzen lass ich mich nicht. At Cafe Leopold, I write the name of each place I’ve visited and jot notes next to their names. It is an attempt to have some reflection on the more memorable experiences in these places—afraid, perhaps, that I would forget. Barcelona, Bratislava, Berlin, Antwerp, and Helmond are all missing entries. There is, finally, a page I recognize as written in my own familiar handwriting on August 2nd. The next day, more truth: I can’t write the same in a notebook. Is a keyboard a method like oil on canvas or pencil on paper? Has my way of creating changed? TO DO: Draw a duck. There is no drawing of a duck because I can barely draw a circle. I had been spending my afternoons sitting on a park bench with a canal view, watching locals float by on rafts and small boats. Another woman came several of the same days, sitting at the bench next to me to paint or draw. I watched the way she started with a white canvas each day and filled it before the afternoon was over with exactly what was in front of her. I wanted to be able to do that in my notebook. I felt like a failure. That my notebook was a waste of my time and talents. I was not a writer. How could I come to all of these places that artists and writers had been inspired by for centuries and not write more than a list of affirmations for myself? I remember the duck I instructed myself to draw. At least you can draw one of these ducks that swims by you every day . But, of course, I could not. Lazy August days on an Amsterdam canal When I open its pages now, six years later, I understand. The spine I was hoping to stuff with experiences and descriptions instead got filled with my worries. I can look back and see how that writing healed me, though. Every apprehension, every failed attempt at giving a panoramic view with my words, was a testament to the parts of me that most needed to be physically present. My travel notebook does not clearly tell or give any stories — it relies on me. Those two months in Europe were experienced outside of my notebook. My anxieties, the worries built up over three previous years, were exposed alongside to-do lists and sloppy notes that only I can fully understand. The writing was secondary in a way I thought it needed to be primary. I had used writing to cope for so long that I forgot I could just observe and enjoy. I was coming into myself as an adult with answers and solutions. My travel notebook does not clearly tell or give any stories — it relies on me. My memories. That a bus number, the name of a drink or a bridge, the type of tea leaves I picked, will transport me back. And they do. These facts let me reach for moments and flavors and scents and names, experiencing them all over again. When I open that notebook, I am able to think of more moments than I could have ever fit in its pages. The final page of the notebook ends with these lines and they remain true: I’ve learned my head still spins everywhere, but it is beautiful. Capable, lovable. Crazy, intolerant. So many things, but still me. Graffiti in Bratislava
title_html: On Keeping a Travel Notebook

On Keeping a Travel Notebook

My summer in Europe was full of remarkable moments — but I forgot to write any of them down

Amanda Oliver
Mar 19

On a Tuesday in March of 2013, hidden in the back room of the Washington, D.C. elementary school library where I worked, I felt myself giving up. On my choice of career and on myself. I was unhappy in the way people in their mid-twenties often are. I felt certain that my two degrees meant I was an adult, but also that I was waiting for an actual adult to tell me what to do. It was my second year working in a school, and I was still anxious at the beginning and end of every day.

That March, my first-grade students were working on a unit about maps and my library was home to 20 globes for them to use as reference. They were situated like orbs on top of the bookshelves I had been painstakingly stocking and reorganizing for a year and a half. The world seemed smaller and manageable when I looked at the globes.

For first graders, though, globes are confusing.

Why can’t I go from D.C. to California if it is only the length of my palm? one asked, pressing his small hand across the continent, middle fingers dipping into the Pacific, almost touching Hawaii. We talked, again, about map scale and I could feel their disappointment with the answer.

When my students left for the day I put a globe on my lap, closed my eyes, and spun it. When I opened them my finger was somewhere in the middle of Africa, holding the world still. I felt an impulsive rush. A summer vacation suddenly felt like exactly what I needed and I booked a one-way ticket to London.

The spine I was hoping to stuff with experiences and descriptions instead got filled with my worries.

From March to the end of June, I secluded myself in the back workroom whenever time allowed and I booked different legs of the trip. I’d only ever traveled to Canada, never outside of North America. I signed up for a help exchange website—a way to secure temporary employment in exchange for shelter and meals—and started to hunt for opportunities: a medicinal garden in Spain, an organic farm in Hungary, helping an older woman with house cleaning in a small town in the Netherlands. I purchased travel insurance, booked hostels and Airbnbs, and chose cities and countries, tracing their locations on one of the library globes.

By April, I was helping to administer standardized tests and had a 10-country, two-month itinerary scrawled on Post-it notes stuck to the table where I fixed the spines and pages of broken books.

A few days after the school year ended, I carefully filled a large red backpack a friend lent me. The date of my departure, June 27th, 2013 is captured on the first page of a new notebook:

I’m here. It’s starting. My arm is rubbed raw from my backpack straps — I’m a pack mule now! When I was little I would write in my old diaries with the idea of my daughter someday reading them. I think I thought I would have her by now — instead I have this trip (and many other insteads, too!). Maybe someday she will read this, if there is a she to read.

I had a panic attack there, in the Washington Dulles airport. The only hint in my notebook is that the second paragraph has a few smeared words from water spots. (It is more enjoyable, even now, to believe that these marks are from the weeks ahead, from the Amsterdam canal, or drops out of the Danube, but I know they are from my doubtful tears.)

During my three years as a librarian, I fit writing into the hours after work. When the sun had set, but my fingers still had something to say. Writing took place in the tiny spaces of time I made for myself when my body felt exhausted, but the center of my chest was wide awake. I knew when I booked my trip that I would use this time, this endless free time, to write. I knew whatever notebook I brought with me would be one I’d cherish for the rest of my life.

I knew these things until I actually left and tried to write in one.

The first country I traveled to was Iceland. I only had one full day in the country and planned to visit the Blue Lagoon. The second page of my notebook reads: “The blue lagoon was beautiful, of course.” This was, apparently, the best I could do. Now, when I look back at pictures, I wish I had described the milky blue water and how I pretended I was sinking into a bowl of Easter egg dye. That its color matched the patent-leather Mary Jane shoes I wore when I was three or four. I wonder why I did not describe its warmth and the way I positioned myself by one vat of the lagoon’s minerals to listen as couples and children approached, giggling as they rubbed the contents onto one another’s faces and shoulders. I was alone, but I was happy.

When I think of anyone traveling for more than a few weeks, I assume they bring a notebook.

The pages from my brief visit to Iceland are filled with worries and wanting to move on to the next destination. I briefly mention hearing a man playing trombone in a room I could not find at the airport and I wish I had lingered there instead of worrying about how I appeared (Did a girl scribbling in her notebook look…crazy? Lonely?). The airport was under construction and many areas were closed off. Sitting in a small circle of café tables surrounded by caution tape, I swore I heard a muffled trombone behind a closed door, a sound I was used to hearing from my middle and high school band days. The auditory version of riding a bike — no matter how it’s been, you always remember. I boarded the plane to London without ever seeing anyone exit a room with a trombone.

London is no better described in my notebook. I briefly mention meeting a woman named Kari and immediately move to complaining about how I always end up next to children on airplanes. I wrote “Hopefully Nice will be nice” before I’d even landed in London. Where is the space for the two-hour long conversation I had with Kari? Any admission that I overpacked and threw two pairs of shoes, a sweatshirt, a dress, and a backpack into an airport trash can upon arrival? Where is the description of the way London smelled — I can’t remember now — when I got off of the plane or how Kari and I decided, together, to sneak into Westminster Abbey rather than paying?

Nice was nice. Nowhere in my notebook will it tell you that I saw the Tour de France, though. That I stood inches from the cyclists as they whizzed by the downtown area or that I hitchhiked for the first time in my life with a BBC reporter. The reporter and I ended up in a car with a French man who talked about his dislike of Americans the entire drive.

There is nothing about how my feet got cut open from running barefoot to catch the last of a fireworks display with an Irish man I had met earlier in the day. That we could have slept on the beach together, but I panicked in the middle of making out with him and gave a taxi driver every bill and coin of money I had in my purse to take me back to my hostel at 2 a.m. There is no report on the pushy Portuguese man who, at sunset on the beach, offered me a tiny balloon that, years later, I would realize was heroin. When he asked me to walk just over there so we could try it together, I put it in my purse and excused myself back to the small group of women I had just met. The next morning, when I checked out of the hostel, I left the balloon in the locker I’d used to store my belongings.

When I think of anyone traveling for more than a few weeks, I assume they bring a notebook. Even people who never write must have a desire to take some sort of notes about their experiences, right? The pressure I put on my own notebook (the notebook of a writer, I kept reminding myself) was immense. In each entry, I try a new way of recording all that was happening, of perfecting my understanding of, and participation in, all these new places.

I fly from France to Spain next. Spend a few days in Barcelona before taking a bus deep into Catalonia. During my seven-day work exchange at a medicinal garden in Balaguer, Spain, I write:

JORDI’S 7/8/13 WORK: Melsa tea, sorting grains, lavender tea, malva tea. Early breakfast (7:30) said goodbye to Eli, then work. Sorting grains, making tea.

Cold, hard facts. Nothing to elaborate on the five people I was working with. Nothing to tell about Jordi, the mighty man behind a slow-food movement who studies plants and is letting us all stay in his apartment with him. Each day we sort grains and make tea at a folding table, listening to the Catalan band Manel on Adrià from Barcelona’s phone, surrounded by Jordi’s massive marijuana plants on his back patio. At dinner we each eat one arsenic-soaked almond as a type of vitamin (Jordi says), and for dessert and digestion we chew on the carob we soak in our water glasses during the meal. Some of our food is cooked by solar power and all of it is vegan. I am surprised there is no mention even of the awful way my body adjusts to a garden-fresh vegan diet on the third day. Just a note that I feel like I am gaining weight and it bothers me.

By early July, two weeks into my travels, my notebook almost entirely becomes to-do lists, website links, jotted notes, walking and public transportation directions, reference numbers for flights. The handwriting does not look like my own. It ignores the straight lines the notebook has provided. It is large and chaotic.

There is nothing written about the nine days I spent wandering bridges and streets in Budapest. That I stayed near the House of Terror, a museum with exhibits related to the fascist and communist regimes in 20th-century Hungary, and watched an elderly woman collapse in the basement there, surrounded by torture cells. Some of them had small windows where you could see the shadows of passing feet on the streets. Visitors were able to enter and stand in each one.

I went to an organ concert at St. Stephen’s Basilica alone — the music from the organ built in 1905 shook the ground beneath my feet. I cried then, situated in the front row. The organ player smiled and winked at me from his seat onstage.

Missing, too, is the story of the very naked, very angry Hungarian man who yelled at me for sunbathing and taking photographs on a rooftop at Széchenyi thermal bath. I had no idea I had ventured onto the naturalist rooftop and that my bathing suit and photography were deeply offensive. His broken English and my complete lack of Hungarian meant the conversation carried on for quite a while before I skittered away from him and noticed a small sign near the entrance that read “Naturalist Rooftop Terrace” in English. At Király Baths I yelped when the masseuse whipped my bathing suit bottom off during the 15-minute massage included with the entry fee and began my kneading my butt. My notebook leaves out these embarrassments.

The arrangements for my spontaneous visit to Vienna are not recorded either. I stayed 10 days just outside of Vienna in the small town of Klosterneuburg with a woman named Sigrid who had recently lost her father. In exchange for helping her clear all of the dead plants off of her patio and refinishing her outdoor furniture, she provided me with a private bedroom and all of my meals. Sigrid’s parents had given her a backpack when she was 14 and sent her on a solo trip to London that awakened her love of travel and hosting others. She introduced me to café culture and the Viennese phrase, “I don’t let myself be pushed.” In Germany, she tells me, it is a literal sentence. In Vienna, it speaks to strength and independence. Over drinks at the Museumsquartier, a place I visit four additional times for the many galleries filled with artwork by artists like Klimt and Schiele, she writes the words in my notebook for me.

Hetzen lass ich mich nicht.

At Cafe Leopold, I write the name of each place I’ve visited and jot notes next to their names. It is an attempt to have some reflection on the more memorable experiences in these places—afraid, perhaps, that I would forget.

Barcelona, Bratislava, Berlin, Antwerp, and Helmond are all missing entries.

There is, finally, a page I recognize as written in my own familiar handwriting on August 2nd.

The next day, more truth:

I can’t write the same in a notebook. Is a keyboard a method like oil on canvas or pencil on paper? Has my way of creating changed? TO DO: Draw a duck.

There is no drawing of a duck because I can barely draw a circle. I had been spending my afternoons sitting on a park bench with a canal view, watching locals float by on rafts and small boats. Another woman came several of the same days, sitting at the bench next to me to paint or draw. I watched the way she started with a white canvas each day and filled it before the afternoon was over with exactly what was in front of her. I wanted to be able to do that in my notebook.

I felt like a failure. That my notebook was a waste of my time and talents. I was not a writer. How could I come to all of these places that artists and writers had been inspired by for centuries and not write more than a list of affirmations for myself? I remember the duck I instructed myself to draw. At least you can draw one of these ducks that swims by you every day. But, of course, I could not.

When I open its pages now, six years later, I understand. The spine I was hoping to stuff with experiences and descriptions instead got filled with my worries. I can look back and see how that writing healed me, though. Every apprehension, every failed attempt at giving a panoramic view with my words, was a testament to the parts of me that most needed to be physically present.

My travel notebook does not clearly tell or give any stories — it relies on me.

Those two months in Europe were experienced outside of my notebook. My anxieties, the worries built up over three previous years, were exposed alongside to-do lists and sloppy notes that only I can fully understand. The writing was secondary in a way I thought it needed to be primary. I had used writing to cope for so long that I forgot I could just observe and enjoy. I was coming into myself as an adult with answers and solutions.

My travel notebook does not clearly tell or give any stories — it relies on me. My memories. That a bus number, the name of a drink or a bridge, the type of tea leaves I picked, will transport me back. And they do. These facts let me reach for moments and flavors and scents and names, experiencing them all over again. When I open that notebook, I am able to think of more moments than I could have ever fit in its pages.

The final page of the notebook ends with these lines and they remain true:

I’ve learned my head still spins everywhere, but it is beautiful. Capable, lovable. Crazy, intolerant. So many things, but still me.

title: On Keeping a Travel Notebook
content_html:
On Keeping a Travel Notebook

My summer in Europe was full of remarkable moments — but I forgot to write any of them down

Amanda Oliver
Mar 19

On a Tuesday in March of 2013, hidden in the back room of the Washington, D.C. elementary school library where I worked, I felt myself giving up. On my choice of career and on myself. I was unhappy in the way people in their mid-twenties often are. I felt certain that my two degrees meant I was an adult, but also that I was waiting for an actual adult to tell me what to do. It was my second year working in a school, and I was still anxious at the beginning and end of every day.

That March, my first-grade students were working on a unit about maps and my library was home to 20 globes for them to use as reference. They were situated like orbs on top of the bookshelves I had been painstakingly stocking and reorganizing for a year and a half. The world seemed smaller and manageable when I looked at the globes.

For first graders, though, globes are confusing.

Why can’t I go from D.C. to California if it is only the length of my palm? one asked, pressing his small hand across the continent, middle fingers dipping into the Pacific, almost touching Hawaii. We talked, again, about map scale and I could feel their disappointment with the answer.

When my students left for the day I put a globe on my lap, closed my eyes, and spun it. When I opened them my finger was somewhere in the middle of Africa, holding the world still. I felt an impulsive rush. A summer vacation suddenly felt like exactly what I needed and I booked a one-way ticket to London.

The spine I was hoping to stuff with experiences and descriptions instead got filled with my worries.

I signed up for a help exchange website—a way to secure temporary employment in exchange for shelter and meals—and started to hunt for opportunities: a medicinal garden in Spain, an organic farm in Hungary, helping an older woman with house cleaning in a small town in the Netherlands. I’m here. It’s starting. My arm is rubbed raw from my backpack straps — I’m a pack mule now! When I was little I would write in my old diaries with the idea of my daughter someday reading them. I think I thought I would have her by now — instead I have this trip (and many other insteads, too!). Maybe someday she will read this, if there is a she to read.

I had a panic attack there, in the Washington Dulles airport. The only hint in my notebook is that the second paragraph has a few smeared words from water spots. (It is more enjoyable, even now, to believe that these marks are from the weeks ahead, from the Amsterdam canal, or drops out of the Danube, but I know they are from my doubtful tears.)

During my three years as a librarian, I fit writing into the hours after work. When the sun had set, but my fingers still had something to say. Writing took place in the tiny spaces of time I made for myself when my body felt exhausted, but the center of my chest was wide awake. I knew when I booked my trip that I would use this time, this endless free time, to write. I knew whatever notebook I brought with me would be one I’d cherish for the rest of my life.

I knew these things until I actually left and tried to write in one.

The first country I traveled to was Iceland. I only had one full day in the country and planned to visit the Blue Lagoon. The second page of my notebook reads: “The blue lagoon was beautiful, of course.” This was, apparently, the best I could do. Now, when I look back at pictures, I wish I had described the milky blue water and how I pretended I was sinking into a bowl of Easter egg dye. That its color matched the patent-leather Mary Jane shoes I wore when I was three or four. I wonder why I did not describe its warmth and the way I positioned myself by one vat of the lagoon’s minerals to listen as couples and children approached, giggling as they rubbed the contents onto one another’s faces and shoulders. I was alone, but I was happy.

When I think of anyone traveling for more than a few weeks, I assume they bring a notebook.

The pages from my brief visit to Iceland are filled with worries and wanting to move on to the next destination. I briefly mention hearing a man playing trombone in a room I could not find at the airport and I wish I had lingered there instead of worrying about how I appeared (Did a girl scribbling in her notebook look…crazy? Lonely?). The airport was under construction and many areas were closed off. Sitting in a small circle of café tables surrounded by caution tape, I swore I heard a muffled trombone behind a closed door, a sound I was used to hearing from my middle and high school band days. The auditory version of riding a bike — no matter how it’s been, you always remember. I boarded the plane to London without ever seeing anyone exit a room with a trombone.

London is no better described in my notebook. I briefly mention meeting a woman named Kari and immediately move to complaining about how I always end up next to children on airplanes. I wrote “Hopefully Nice will be nice” before I’d even landed in London. Where is the space for the two-hour long conversation I had with Kari? Any admission that I overpacked and threw two pairs of shoes, a sweatshirt, a dress, and a backpack into an airport trash can upon arrival? Where is the description of the way London smelled — I can’t remember now — when I got off of the plane or how Kari and I decided, together, to sneak into Westminster Abbey rather than paying?

Nice was nice. Nowhere in my notebook will it tell you that I saw the Tour de France, though. That I stood inches from the cyclists as they whizzed by the downtown area or that I hitchhiked for the first time in my life with a BBC reporter. The reporter and I ended up in a car with a French man who talked about his dislike of Americans the entire drive.

There is nothing about how my feet got cut open from running barefoot to catch the last of a fireworks display with an Irish man I had met earlier in the day. That we could have slept on the beach together, but I panicked in the middle of making out with him and gave a taxi driver every bill and coin of money I had in my purse to take me back to my hostel at 2 a.m. There is no report on the pushy Portuguese man who, at sunset on the beach, offered me a tiny balloon that, years later, I would realize was heroin. When he asked me to walk just over there so we could try it together, I put it in my purse and excused myself back to the small group of women I had just met. The next morning, when I checked out of the hostel, I left the balloon in the locker I’d used to store my belongings.

When I think of anyone traveling for more than a few weeks, I assume they bring a notebook. Even people who never write must have a desire to take some sort of notes about their experiences, right? The pressure I put on my own notebook (the notebook of a writer, I kept reminding myself) was immense. In each entry, I try a new way of recording all that was happening, of perfecting my understanding of, and participation in, all these new places.

I fly from France to Spain next. Spend a few days in Barcelona before taking a bus deep into Catalonia. During my seven-day work exchange at a medicinal garden in Balaguer, Spain, I write:

JORDI’S 7/8/13 WORK: Melsa tea, sorting grains, lavender tea, malva tea. Early breakfast (7:30) said goodbye to Eli, then work. Sorting grains, making tea.

Cold, hard facts. Nothing to elaborate on the five people I was working with. Nothing to tell about Jordi, the mighty man behind a slow-food movement who studies plants and is letting us all stay in his apartment with him. Each day we sort grains and make tea at a folding table, listening to the Catalan band Manel on Adrià from Barcelona’s phone, surrounded by Jordi’s massive marijuana plants on his back patio. At dinner we each eat one arsenic-soaked almond as a type of vitamin (Jordi says), and for dessert and digestion we chew on the carob we soak in our water glasses during the meal. Some of our food is cooked by solar power and all of it is vegan. I am surprised there is no mention even of the awful way my body adjusts to a garden-fresh vegan diet on the third day. Just a note that I feel like I am gaining weight and it bothers me.

By early July, two weeks into my travels, my notebook almost entirely becomes to-do lists, website links, jotted notes, walking and public transportation directions, reference numbers for flights. The handwriting does not look like my own. It ignores the straight lines the notebook has provided. It is large and chaotic.

There is nothing written about the nine days I spent wandering bridges and streets in Budapest. That I stayed near the House of Terror, a museum with exhibits related to the fascist and communist regimes in 20th-century Hungary, and watched an elderly woman collapse in the basement there, surrounded by torture cells. Some of them had small windows where you could see the shadows of passing feet on the streets. Visitors were able to enter and stand in each one.

I went to an organ concert at St. Stephen’s Basilica alone — the music from the organ built in 1905 shook the ground beneath my feet. I cried then, situated in the front row. The organ player smiled and winked at me from his seat onstage.

Missing, too, is the story of the very naked, very angry Hungarian man who yelled at me for sunbathing and taking photographs on a rooftop at Széchenyi thermal bath. I had no idea I had ventured onto the naturalist rooftop and that my bathing suit and photography were deeply offensive. His broken English and my complete lack of Hungarian meant the conversation carried on for quite a while before I skittered away from him and noticed a small sign near the entrance that read “Naturalist Rooftop Terrace” in English. At Király Baths I yelped when the masseuse whipped my bathing suit bottom off during the 15-minute massage included with the entry fee and began my kneading my butt. My notebook leaves out these embarrassments.

The arrangements for my spontaneous visit to Vienna are not recorded either. I stayed 10 days just outside of Vienna in the small town of Klosterneuburg with a woman named Sigrid who had recently lost her father. In exchange for helping her clear all of the dead plants off of her patio and refinishing her outdoor furniture, she provided me with a private bedroom and all of my meals. Sigrid’s parents had given her a backpack when she was 14 and sent her on a solo trip to London that awakened her love of travel and hosting others. She introduced me to café culture and the Viennese phrase, “I don’t let myself be pushed.” In Germany, she tells me, it is a literal sentence. In Vienna, it speaks to strength and independence. Over drinks at the Museumsquartier, a place I visit four additional times for the many galleries filled with artwork by artists like Klimt and Schiele, she writes the words in my notebook for me.

Hetzen lass ich mich nicht.

At Cafe Leopold, I write the name of each place I’ve visited and jot notes next to their names. It is an attempt to have some reflection on the more memorable experiences in these places—afraid, perhaps, that I would forget.

Barcelona, Bratislava, Berlin, Antwerp, and Helmond are all missing entries.

There is, finally, a page I recognize as written in my own familiar handwriting on August 2nd.

The next day, more truth:

I can’t write the same in a notebook. Is a keyboard a method like oil on canvas or pencil on paper? Has my way of creating changed? TO DO: Draw a duck.

There is no drawing of a duck because I can barely draw a circle. I had been spending my afternoons sitting on a park bench with a canal view, watching locals float by on rafts and small boats. Another woman came several of the same days, sitting at the bench next to me to paint or draw. I watched the way she started with a white canvas each day and filled it before the afternoon was over with exactly what was in front of her. I wanted to be able to do that in my notebook.

I felt like a failure. That my notebook was a waste of my time and talents. I was not a writer. How could I come to all of these places that artists and writers had been inspired by for centuries and not write more than a list of affirmations for myself? I remember the duck I instructed myself to draw. At least you can draw one of these ducks that swims by you every day. But, of course, I could not.

When I open its pages now, six years later, I understand. The spine I was hoping to stuff with experiences and descriptions instead got filled with my worries. I can look back and see how that writing healed me, though. Every apprehension, every failed attempt at giving a panoramic view with my words, was a testament to the parts of me that most needed to be physically present.

My travel notebook does not clearly tell or give any stories — it relies on me.

Those two months in Europe were experienced outside of my notebook. My anxieties, the worries built up over three previous years, were exposed alongside to-do lists and sloppy notes that only I can fully understand. The writing was secondary in a way I thought it needed to be primary. I had used writing to cope for so long that I forgot I could just observe and enjoy. I was coming into myself as an adult with answers and solutions.

My travel notebook does not clearly tell or give any stories — it relies on me. My memories. That a bus number, the name of a drink or a bridge, the type of tea leaves I picked, will transport me back. And they do. These facts let me reach for moments and flavors and scents and names, experiencing them all over again. When I open that notebook, I am able to think of more moments than I could have ever fit in its pages.

The final page of the notebook ends with these lines and they remain true:

I’ve learned my head still spins everywhere, but it is beautiful. Capable, lovable. Crazy, intolerant. So many things, but still me.
